awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Headwater stream networks in a warming world: predicting heterotrophic ecosystem function using theory, multi-scale temperature manipulations and modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's river systems receive, transport, store, and break down a substantial proportion of the dead plant material produced in terrestrial ecosystems. Many of the steps in the breakdown of this organic matter are greatly affected by water temperature, which is increasing along with air temperature globally. While the effects of temperature on some of these steps are understood relatively well at small scales, it remains an open question how they interact as a complex, integrated ecosystem-level process to drive the effects of rising temperatures at the large spatial and temporal scales over which Earth's river systems operate. Consequently, research is needed that tests the effects of temperature on organic matter breakdown in whole ecosystems, with the explicit goal of scaling up these results to understand how entire river reaches and networks process organic matter. This project will use data from temperature manipulations at multiple spatial and temporal scales to: 1) inform ecological theory that uses basic principles to understand how the effects of temperature scale from individual organisms to entire ecosystems; and 2) build a model that simulates the effects of temperature on organic matter processing in an entire forest stream network. This research is important because rising temperatures may alter the global biogeochemical role of streams and rivers in currently unpredictable ways, making the results useful in the future management of river health. An education program will be an integral part of this project and will include the development of a citizen science project, as well as training of undergraduates, graduate students and research technicians.
	Fieldwork for this project will take place at the Coweeta Hydrologic Laboratory, North Carolina, U.S.A., a site with a decades-long history of research on organic matter processing in stream ecosystems. The first objective is to understand how warming affects the organisms (fungi and invertebrates) that are critically important in organic matter breakdown in streams. This component of the project will combine detailed laboratory-based studies of fungi, experiments in heated streamside channels and the warming of an entire reach of a small forest stream to understand how higher temperatures change community structure of fungal and animal decomposers. The second objective is to use the various temperature manipulations to understand how temperature changes pathways and rates of organic matter processing in streams and rivers. The fates of organic matter will be studied using laboratory investigations, streamside channels, and field experiments combined with organic matter budgets and food web descriptions in the experimentally warmed stream and a matching reference stream. The results of these first two objectives will be combined with extensive existing datasets available at the Coweeta site to inform the final objective: construction of an ecological model that predicts the effects of warming on organic matter processing in an entire stream network. This model will also allow incorporation of other important factors that could potentially change in the future, such as precipitation and the relative quality of organic matter that enters stream ecosystems. Together, this research will provide much needed information about how warming influences the important biogeochemical role of streams and rivers.

por.por_cntn:
This project is a collaborative effort that included partners from five universities. The overall goal of the project is to understand and predict the consequences of climate warming for the processing of terrestrial organic carbon in headwater streams. The project provides empirical data concerning the responses of stream communities and carbon flow to changes in temperature regime, benefiting society through increased understanding of how warming influences freshwater ecosystems and the services they provide. To achieve this goal, we studied plant litter processing using natural temperature gradients and experimental thermal manipulations at scales that included laboratory microcosms, streamside channels and entire stream reaches. Since microorganisms are important intermediaries in carbon flow in such systems, our team at Coastal Carolina University focused on "microbial" component of the whole collaborative project. Thus, our specific goal was to examine the responses of microbial parameters (activity, fungal community structure) to warming and if these responses deviate from current predictions.

Specifically, we asked the following questions. (i) Can the effects of temperature be easily explained by the Metabolic Theory of Ecology (MTE)? (ii) Are there differences in response to temperature among parameters of microbial activity and substrates (leaves vs. wood) in streams? (iii) Are the effects of temperature the same across temperatures commonly found in streams (0-20°C)? We found that responses of aquatic litter-associated microorganisms to increases in temperature are more complex than simple MTE predictions. We often obtained higher than expected estimates of apparent activation energy (Ea) for some parameters of microbial activity (e.g., fungal growth rate, activity of enzymes attacking plant carbon) suggesting greater temperature sensitivity. But, unexpectedly, we found that some microbial parameters on wood (respiration, enzyme activity) were less sensitive to temperature increases than on leaf litter. Overall, our findings showed greater temperature sensitivity of microbial processes at lower stream temperatures (4-12°C). Acclimation was also detected only at low temperatures. Our next-generation sequencing data (Illumina) as well as microscopy data (spore counts) showed that larger increases in temperature (in microcosms) caused strong shifts in fungal community structure; however, changes were difficult to detect with moderate temperature increases (up to 4°C in streamside channels). Litter type exerted greater control on fungal communities than temperature. The effects of warming may have important implications for stream fungal communities and ecosystem functioning under climate change scenarios.

Understanding, predicting, and adapting to the effects of climate change is perhaps the most important challenge of the 21st century. Our findings suggest that microorganisms and microbial carbon processing in streams during the cold months could be especially sensitive to temperature changes. These trends may have important implications for stream ecosystems under climate change scenarios, since bulk leaf litter inputs and peak fungal activity coincide with the coldest season (autumn-winter) in temperate streams. This may change the amount and/or timing of microbial CO2 output as well as lead to leaf litter depletion by summer months affecting food availability to higher trophic levels (e.g., starving stream invertebrates).

This project supported three MS students and several undergraduate students (including four Honor's theses) at Coastal Carolina University. Students received training in microbial ecology, participated in sample collection and processing, data analysis and scientific writing. This project resulted in multiple conference presentations and publications; many of those included students as co-authors.
